title: A quick introduction to MetaboCrates
text: MetaboCrates package provides tools processing analyzing targeted metabolomics data (e.g., generated using Biocrates® kits). can easily upload data perform automated preprocessing, data cleaning missing value imputation, followed visualizations descriptive statistics data exploration. package also includes tools quality control outlier detection.

title: A quick introduction to MetaboCrates
text: MetaboCrates can easily installed loaded environment using following commands. Next, metabolomics data can imported read_data() function. guide, example dataset included package used. class dat object data.frame raw_data. following attributes: LOD_table - table containing limits detection (LOD), lower limit quantification (LLOQ), upper limit quantification (ULOQ). counts - types missing values found data counts, NA_ratios_type - fractions missing values type every metabolite, NA_ratios_group - fractions missing values respect group levels every metabolite, metabolites - names metabolites data, samples - names sample types counts, group - names grouping columns (appears using add_group() function), LOD - proportion missing values, QC - coefficient variation (CV), completed - completed data (appears imputation), cv - coefficients variation based QC sample type metabolite (appears using calculate_CV() function). Non-null attributes stage shown . Now, information missing values can displayed.
code: devtools::install_github("BioGenies/MetaboCrates")  library(MetaboCrates) path <- get_example_data("two_sets_example.xlsx") dat <- read_data(path)  get_info(dat) #> [1] "Data contains 13 sample types and 2 NA types." attr(dat, "LOD_table")[,1:5] #>                    plate bar code     C0     C2     C3 C3-DC (C4-OH) #> 1   LOD (calc.) 1052125775-1 [µM]     NA     NA     NA            NA #> 2   LOD (calc.) 1052125780-1 [µM] 0.7702 0.0545 0.0000        0.0206 #> 3   LOD (calc.) 1052126590-1 [µM]     NA     NA     NA            NA #> 4   LOD (calc.) 1052126601-1 [µM] 1.4720 0.0269 0.0000        0.0002 #> 5 LOD (from OP) 1052125775-1 [µM]     NA     NA     NA            NA #> 6 LOD (from OP) 1052125780-1 [µM] 1.6670 0.1333 0.1222        0.0900 #> 7 LOD (from OP) 1052126590-1 [µM]     NA     NA     NA            NA #> 8 LOD (from OP) 1052126601-1 [µM] 1.6670 0.1333 0.1222        0.0900  attr(dat, "NA_info")[["NA_ratios"]][5:10,] #> NULL attr(dat, "NA_info")[["counts"]] #> # A tibble: 2 × 2 #>   type      n #>   <chr> <dbl> #> 1 < LOD 16240 #> 2 NA      316  attr(dat, "metabolites")[1:10] #>  [1] "C0"            "C2"            "C3"            "C3-DC (C4-OH)" #>  [5] "C3-OH"         "C3:1"          "C4"            "C4:1"          #>  [9] "C5"            "C5-DC (C6-OH)"  attr(dat, "samples")[1:5,] #> # A tibble: 5 × 2 #>   `sample type` count #>   <chr>         <int> #> 1 Blank             1 #> 2 QC Level 1        2 #> 3 QC Level 2        6 #> 4 QC Level 3        2 #> 5 Sample          159 attr(dat, "NA_info")[["counts"]] #> # A tibble: 2 × 2 #>   type      n #>   <chr> <dbl> #> 1 < LOD 16240 #> 2 NA      316  plot_mv_types(dat)

title: A quick introduction to MetaboCrates
text: Using add_group() function, can specify columns (must contain missing values) group data . Although step optional, functions require grouped data. grouping,NA_info attribute contains proportion missing values group levels metabolite. Moreover, grouping columns names added group attribute. , information grouped data displayed.
code: grouped_dat <- add_group(dat, c("submission name", "species")) attr(grouped_dat, "NA_info")[["NA_ratios_group"]][5:10,] #> # A tibble: 6 × 3 #>   metabolite grouping_column         NA_frac #>   <chr>      <chr>                     <dbl> #> 1 3-IPA      2023LS_s2, human          0     #> 2 3-IPA      2023_Lukasz_S_s1, human   0     #> 3 3-Met-His  2023LS_s2, human          0     #> 4 3-Met-His  2023_Lukasz_S_s1, human   0     #> 5 5-AVA      2023LS_s2, human          0.114 #> 6 5-AVA      2023_Lukasz_S_s1, human   0.238  attr(grouped_dat, "group") #> [1] "submission name" "species" cat(get_info(grouped_dat)) #> Data contains 13 sample types and 2 NA types. #> Groupping by: "submission name" (4 levels). Data contains 13 sample types and 2 NA types. #> Groupping by: "species" (4 levels).  plot_groups(grouped_dat)

title: A quick introduction to MetaboCrates
text: investigate missing values ratios metabolite, plot_NA_percent() function can used.    grouped data passed, function returns names metabolites given threshold missing values. grouping specified, returns metabolites threshold exceeded group level. examples threshold 20%. grouping 4 levels specified, Venn diagram can created, shows counts metabolites ratios missing values larger given threshold group level.  Finally, can remove chosen metabolites using remove_metabolites() function type specified LOD. Instead actually removing data, function adds provided metabolites removed attribute. , data missing values ratios without removed metabolites can displayed. , first 5 rows tibbles chosen columns first visible. two options restoring metabolites - either specific ones can selected metabolites specified type can restored.
code: example_metabolites <- c("Cys", "TG 18:3_35:2", "Cortisone", "CDCA", "AbsAcid")  plot_NA_percent(grouped_dat, type = "joint", interactive = FALSE) +   ylim(example_metabolites) plot_NA_percent(grouped_dat, type = "NA_type", interactive = FALSE) +   ylim(example_metabolites) plot_NA_percent(grouped_dat, type = "group", interactive = FALSE) +   ylim(example_metabolites) get_LOD_to_remove(dat, 0.2)[1:5] #> [1] "AbsAcid"  "Ac-Orn"   "Anserine" "BABA"     "C10:1"  get_LOD_to_remove(grouped_dat, 0.2)[1:5] #> [1] "AbsAcid"  "Ac-Orn"   "Anserine" "C10:1"    "C10:2" create_venn_diagram(grouped_dat, 0.2) rm_dat <- remove_metabolites(grouped_dat,                              metabolites_to_remove = c("AbsAcid", "Ac-Orn"),                              type = "LOD")  attr(rm_dat, "removed") #> $LOD #> [1] "AbsAcid" "Ac-Orn"  #>  #> $QC #> NULL show_data(rm_dat)[1:5, c(1:3, 19:21)] #>                plate bar code sample bar code sample type    C2     C3 #> 1 1052126590-1 | 1052126601-1        10000001       Blank    NA     NA #> 2 1052125775-1 | 1052125780-1      1020527268  QC Level 1 1.999 0.7022 #> 3 1052126590-1 | 1052126601-1      1020527268  QC Level 1 2.083 0.7166 #> 4 1052125775-1 | 1052125780-1      1020527272  QC Level 2 3.689  1.461 #> 5 1052125775-1 | 1052125780-1      1020527272  QC Level 2 3.088  1.369 #>   C3-DC (C4-OH) #> 1            NA #> 2         < LOD #> 3        0.0134 #> 4        0.0346 #> 5        0.0344  show_ratios(rm_dat)[1:5,] #> # A tibble: 5 × 2 #>   metabolite NA_frac #>   <chr>        <dbl> #> 1 1-Met-His    0     #> 2 3-IAA        0     #> 3 3-IPA        0     #> 4 3-Met-His    0     #> 5 5-AVA        0.176 attr(unremove_metabolites(rm_dat, "AbsAcid"), "removed") #> $LOD #> [1] "Ac-Orn" #>  #> $QC #> NULL  attr(unremove_all(rm_dat, "LOD"), "removed") #> $LOD #> NULL #>  #> $QC #> NULL

title: A quick introduction to MetaboCrates
text: Aside removing metabolites, missing values can also imputed using complete_data() function. completes missing values related limits quantification detection. Imputation values limit detection (< LOD) can performed one seven ways: NULL - skipping imputation, halfmin - half minimum observed value, halflimit - half detection limit, random - random number smaller limit detection bigger minimum observed value, limit - detection limit, limit-0.2min - detection limit minus 0.2 times minimum observed value, logspline - random number logspline density fitted observed values. Values quantification limit (< LLOQ) can imputed using either NULL limit methods. Similarly, values upper limit quantification (> ULOQ) can imputed using NULL limit methods third quartile - third quartile observed values, scaled random - random number higher upper limit quantification lower double. Completed dataset stored completed attribute. investigate missing values, can use plot_heatmap() function, creates heatmap indicating whether value missing sample metabolite, depending plate bar code. can specify plate bar code generate single plot; otherwise, multiple plate bar codes dataset, faceted plot created. show_colors = TRUE, missing value type shown different color. , cropped plots presented, showing first five metabolites.   Next, can compare distributions individual metabolite imputation. create_distribution_plot() function can generate histogram, density plot, beeswarm plot (either regular interactive tooltips). Additionally, histogram, can choose display either values imputation previously missing imputed.     MetaboCrates also offers two types Q-Q plots: theoretical Q-Q plot (using create_qqplot() function), compares quantiles metabolite quantiles normal distribution, empirical Q-Q plot (create_empirical_qqplot()), compares quantiles metabolite values imputation.   imputation, can perform quality control outlier detection.
code: comp_dat <- complete_data(rm_dat,                           LOD_method = "halfmin",                           LLOQ_method = "limit",                           ULOQ_method = "third quartile") plot_heatmap(comp_dat, plate_bar_code = "1052125775-1 | 1052125780-1") +    ylim(attr(comp_dat, "metabolites")[5:1]) plot_heatmap(comp_dat) +    ylim(attr(comp_dat, "metabolites")[5:1]) create_distribution_plot(comp_dat, metabolite = "C9", bins = 40) create_distribution_plot(comp_dat, metabolite = "C9", bins = 40,                          histogram_type = "imputed") create_distribution_plot(comp_dat, metabolite = "C9", type = "density") create_distribution_plot(comp_dat, metabolite = "C9",                          type = "beeswarm") create_qqplot(comp_dat, metabolite = "C9") create_empirical_qqplot(comp_dat, metabolite = "C9")

title: A quick introduction to MetaboCrates
text: perform quality control, must calculate coefficients variation (CV) quality control type using completed data. coefficients variation can now accessed cv attribute. can obtain metabolites CV values greater specified threshold using following function. remove metabolites data, use remove_metabolites() function.
code: qc_dat <- calculate_CV(comp_dat) attr(qc_dat, "cv")[1:5,] #> # A tibble: 5 × 3 #>   `sample type` metabolite      CV #>   <chr>         <chr>        <dbl> #> 1 QC Level 1    1-Met-His  0.0392  #> 2 QC Level 1    3-IAA      0.00646 #> 3 QC Level 1    3-IPA      0.0252  #> 4 QC Level 1    3-Met-His  0.0322  #> 5 QC Level 1    5-AVA      0.0722 get_CV_to_remove(qc_dat, 0.8)[1:5] #> [1] "C14:1"          "C3-DC (C4-OH)"  "Cer d18:1/26:0" "Cer d18:2/18:0" #> [5] "DG 14:1_18:1" qc_dat <- remove_metabolites(qc_dat, c("C14:1", "C3-DC (C4-OH)"), "QC")  attr(qc_dat, "removed") #> $LOD #> [1] "AbsAcid" "Ac-Orn"  #>  #> $QC #> [1] "C14:1"         "C3-DC (C4-OH)"

title: A quick introduction to MetaboCrates
text: detect outliers patterns corresponding variation data, can use principal component analysis (PCA). MetaboCrates offers several PCA plots. function creates PCA scatterplots, visualize clustering observations respect sample type group level. Using function, can also generate biplots (based data sample types group_by = "sample_type", type Sample group_by = "group"), displaying loadings given threshold. plot type illustrates metabolite contributes first two principal components highlights metabolites capture similar information.   Finally, can investigate percentage total variance data explained principal component. Additionally, cumulative variance - sum percentage variance contributions first principal component given component - can displayed. Threshold determines principal components shown: components cumulative variance remains threshold included, along one additional component brings cumulative variance just threshold (applicable). can also specify maximum number principal components display plot.
code: create_PCA_plot(qc_dat,                 types_to_display = c("Sample", "QC Level 1", "QC Level 2")) create_PCA_plot(qc_dat, group_by = "group") create_PCA_plot(qc_dat, type = "biplot", threshold = 0.05, interactive = FALSE) create_PCA_plot(qc_dat, type = "biplot", group_by = "group", threshold = 0.05,                 interactive = FALSE) pca_variance(qc_dat, threshold = 0.7) pca_variance(qc_dat, threshold = 0.7, group_by = "group", max_num = 6,              cumulative = FALSE)

title: Processing and Analysis of Biocrates® Metabolomics Data
text: MetaboCrates designed early analysis data obtained targeted metabolomics, e.g., Biocrates® kits. simplifies streamlines data processing workflow, allowing efficiently analyze metabolite data. ’s brief overview key features:

title: Processing and Analysis of Biocrates® Metabolomics Data
text: 1. Data Import: Easily import metabolomics data generated Biocrates® platforms. 2. Preprocessing: Perform data preprocessing tasks metabolites selection <LOD imputation. Automatically identify remove metabolites high Limit Detection (LOD) proportion. Enhance accuracy data eliminating unreliable measurements. Complete missing data points metabolites based LOD values. Ensure dataset comprehensive suitable analysis. 3. Quality Control: Quality control checks data. 4. Analysis: Calculate descriptive statistics. 5. Save work: Save progress, allowing resume analysis later time. Track manage multiple projects effortlessly. Easily share findings colleagues collaborators.

TRUE (default), ggiraph interactive plot returned; otherwise, standard ggplot object produced.
